Designs for non-normal Endpoints with approximately normal test statistics

Source: vignettes/other-endpoints.Rmd
other-endpoints.Rmd

Currently, adoptr supports the optimization of adaptive two-stage designs with either normally or t-distributed test statistics. More specifically, it is required that the first stage test statistic, and the distribution of the second stage test-statistic conditional on the first-stage test statistic, is either normal or t-distributed.

When individual observations are normally distributed, stage-wise Z- or T-test statistics fulfill these criteria. In practice, however, there are many situations where one cannot reasonably assume that individual observations are sampled from a normal distribution. It is common for trials to be conducted for binary or time-to-event endpoints, e.g.¬†if one is interested in investigating the impact of a drug on mortality. One way to deal with this situation is by transforming the data to a test-statistic which is approximately normal. In the following, we will explain how to do so for binary and for time-to-event endpoints.

We will be using the following notation:

  • XiTX_i^T will denote an observation of recruit ii in the treatment arm
  • XiCX_i^C will denote the observation of recruit ii in the control arm
  • nn will denote the group-wise sample size.

Binary endpoints

Binary endpoints are endpoints where individual observations follow a Bernoulli distribution, i.e.¬†XiT‚àºBin(1,pT)X_i^T \sim Bin(1,p_T) and XiC‚àºBin(1,pC)X_i^C\sim Bin(1,p_C). Our goal is to compare the probability pTp_T of an event in the treatment group with a fixed value (single-arm trial) or with the probability pCp_C of an event in the control group (two-armed trial). Thus, assuming that larger probabilities are favorable, we have

H0:pT‚â§pCvs.H1:pT>pC. H_0: p_T \leq p_C\quad \text{vs.} \quad H_1:p_T > p_C.

To test this hypothesis, one could use the test statistic U=n2pÃÇT‚àípÃÇCpÃÇ0(1‚àípÃÇ0), U=\sqrt{\frac{n}{2}}\frac{\hat{p}_T-\hat{p}_C}{\sqrt{\hat{p}_0(1-\hat{p}_0)}},

where pÃÇT=1n‚àëinXiT\hat{p}_T=\frac{1}{n}\sum_i^{n}X_i^T and pÃÇC=1n‚àëinXiC\hat{p}_C=\frac{1}{n}\sum_i^{n}X_i^C are the maximum likelihood estimators of pTp_T and pCp_C and where pÃÇ0=1n‚àëinXiT+1n‚àëinXiC2\hat{p}_0=\frac{\frac{1}{n}\sum_i^{n}X_i^T+\frac{1}{n}\sum_i^{n}X_i^C}{2}.

The outcome of UU is then compared to cfc_f and cec_e, the first stage boundaries. If U‚àà[cf,ce]U\in [c_f,c_e], we continue the trial and compute a new value for U2U_2 in the second stage, where we reject the null if U2>c2U_2>c_2.

It is a well-known fact that this test statistic is asymptotically normal, and we will give a proof of this in the next section.

Asymptotic distribution of the test statistic

We begin with the difference pÃÇT‚àípÃÇC\hat{p}_T-\hat{p}_C. Using the de Moivre-Laplace theorem, we get that npÃÇT‚àínpTn‚Üídùí©(0,pT(1‚àípT)). \frac{n\hat{p}_T-np_T}{\sqrt{n}} \overset{d}{\to} \mathcal{N}(0,p_T(1-p_T)). After defining œÉA2=pT(1‚àípT)+pC(1‚àípC)\sigma_A^2=p_T(1-p_T)+p_C(1-p_C), we obtain npÃÇT‚àínpTn‚àínpÃÇC‚àínpCn=n(pÃÇT‚àípÃÇC‚àí(pT‚àípC))‚Üídùí©(0,œÉA2), \frac{n\hat{p}_T-np_T}{\sqrt{n}}-\frac{n\hat{p}_C-np_C}{\sqrt{n}}=\sqrt{n}(\hat{p}_T-\hat{p}_C-(p_T-p_C))\overset{d}{\to}\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma_A^2), so it follows n(pÃÇT‚àípÃÇC)‚Üídùí©(n(pT‚àípc),œÉA2). \sqrt{n}(\hat{p}_T-\hat{p}_C)\overset{d}{\to}\mathcal{N}(\sqrt{n}(p_T-p_c),\sigma_A^2). Applying the continuous mapping theorem, it results that œÉÃÇ0:=2pÃÇ0(1‚àípÃÇ0)‚ÜíP2p0(1‚àíp0):=œÉ0\hat{\sigma}_0:=\sqrt{2\hat{p}_0(1-\hat{p}_0)} \overset{P}{\to}\sqrt{2p_0(1-p_0)}:=\sigma_0, so by Slutzky‚Äôs theorem, we get n(pÃÇT‚àípÃÇC)œÉ0=n2pÃÇT‚àípÃÇCpÃÇ0(1‚àípÃÇ0)‚Üídùí©(npT‚àípCœÉ0,œÉA2œÉ02). \frac{\sqrt{n}(\hat{p}_T-\hat{p}_C)}{\sigma_0}=\sqrt{\frac{n}{2}}\frac{\hat{p}_T-\hat{p}_C}{\sqrt{\hat{p}_0(1-\hat{p}_0)}}\overset{d}{\to}\mathcal{N}\left(\sqrt{n}\frac{p_T-p_C}{\sigma_0},\frac{\sigma_A^2}{\sigma_0^2}\right). Hence, for sufficiently large nn, UU is approximately normal.

Note that under the null hypothesis, œÉA2=œÉ02\sigma_A^2=\sigma_0^2 and pT=pCp_T=p_C. Thus, approximately, U‚àºùí©(0,1)U\sim \mathcal{N}(0,1) under H0H_0.

adoptr and binomial endpoints

Implementation details

Currently, adoptr only supports the specification of a single fixed reference value fo pCp_C, while general prior distributions are supported for the effect size Œ∏\theta.

This is a limitation, as uncertainty about the control group rate cannot be represented in this framework. However, in a trial comparing a new treatment to an existing one, it is usually reasonable to assume that some information about the event rate in the control group is available beforehand.

Example

Assume we want to plan a two-armed trial with an assumed rate of events in the control group of pC=0.3p_C=0.3. These parameters are encoded in the DataDistribution object.

datadist <- Binomial(0.3, two_armed = TRUE)

Let us furthermore postulate a normal prior distribution for Œ∏\theta with expectation Œº=0.2\mu=0.2 and standard deviation œÉ=0.2\sigma=0.2, which was truncated to the interval (‚àí.29,0.69)(-.29,0.69). It is necessary to use a truncation to ensure that pT‚àà(0,1)p_T \in (0,1).

H_0        <- PointMassPrior(.0, 1)
prior      <- ContinuousPrior(function(x) 1 / (pnorm(0.69, 0.2, 0.2) - 
                                                   pnorm(-0.29, 0.2, 0.2)) * 
                                  dnorm(x, 0.2, 0.2),
                              support = c(-0.29,0.69),
                              tighten_support = TRUE)

We require a maximal type one error of Œ±‚â§0.025\alpha\leq 0.025 and a minimum expected power of ùîº[1‚àíŒ≤]‚â•0.8\mathbb{E}[1-\beta]\geq 0.8.

alpha      <- 0.025
min_epower <- 0.8
toer_cnstr <- Power(datadist, H_0) <= alpha
epow_cnstr <- Power(datadist, condition(prior, c(0.0,0.69))) >= min_epower

Next, we need to choose an objective function, which will be the expected sample size under the chosen prior distribution for Œ∏\theta in this example. After having chosen a starting point for the optimization procedure, we use the minimize function to determine the optimal design parameters.

ess <- ExpectedSampleSize(datadist,prior)

init <- get_initial_design(0.2,0.025,0.2)

opt_design <- minimize(ess,subject_to(toer_cnstr,epow_cnstr), 
                       initial_design = init, check_constraints = TRUE)
#> Warning in minimize(ess, subject_to(toer_cnstr, epow_cnstr), initial_design =
#> init, : NLOPT_MAXEVAL_REACHED: Optimization stopped because maxeval (above) was
#> reached.

plot(opt_design$design)

Time-to-event endpoints

Time-to-event endpoints are another common type of endpoint used in clinical trials. Time-to-event data is two-dimensional and consists of an indicator denoting the occurrence of an event or censoring, and a time of the event or censoring.

A common effect measure for time-to-event endpoints is the so called hazard-ratio, which is the ratio of hazard functions between two groups or the ratio of the hazard of one group and a postulated baseline hazard.

In the following, the hazard ratio will be denoted by Œ∏:=ŒªC(t)ŒªT(t)\theta := \frac{\lambda_C(t)}{\lambda_T(t)}, and we will assume that Œ∏\theta is constant over time. Assuming that less hazard is favorable, the resulting hypotheses to be tested are

H0:Œ∏‚â§1vs.H1:Œ∏>1. H_0: \theta\leq 1 \quad \text{vs.} \quad H_1: \theta >1.

Let 1,‚Ä¶,J1,\dots,J be the distinct times of observed events in either group and let nT,j,nC,jn_{T,j}, n_{C,j} be the number of subjects, who neither had an event nor have been censored. Additionally, let OT,j,OC,jO_{T,j},O_{C,j} denote the observed number of events at time jj. In the following we assume that there are no ties, so OT,j,OC,j‚àà{0,1}O_{T,j},O_{C,j}\in \{0,1\}. Define nj:=nT,j+nC,jn_j:=n_{T,j}+n_{C,j} and Oj:=OT,j+OC,jO_j:= O_{T,j}+O_{C,j}. Under the null, the hazard functions of the groups are equal. Thus, for i‚àà{T,C}i \in \{T,C\}, Oi,jO_{i,j} can be regarded as the number of events in a draw of size ni,jn_{i,j}, where the population has size njn_j. Therefore, Oi,jO_{i,j} follows a hypergeometric distribution, i.e.¬†Oi,j‚àºh(nj,Oj,ni,j)O_{i,j}\sim h(n_j,O_j,n_{i,j}). This distribution has an expected value of Ei,j:=ùîº[Oi,j]=ni,jOjnjE_{i,j}:=\mathbb{E}[O_{i,j}]=n_{i,j}\frac{O_j}{n_j} and variance Vi,j:=Var(Oi,j)=Ei,j(nj‚àíOjnj)(nj‚àíni,jnj‚àí1)V_{i,j}:=\text{Var}(O_{i,j})=E_{i,j}\left(\frac{n_j-O_j}{n_j}\right)\left(\frac{n_j-n_{i,j}}{n_j-1}\right). Using these definitions, we can define the so-called log-rank test statistic as

L=LT:=‚àëj=1JOT,j‚àíET,j‚àëj=1JVT,j. L=L_T:=\frac{\sum_{j=1}^J O_{T,j}-E_{T,j}}{\sqrt{\sum_{j=1}^J V_{T,j}}}. Note that it does not matter whether we consider LTL_T or the analogously defined statistic LCL_C, both of them yield the same results, so we abbreviate LTL_T to LL. By the central limit theorem, it is easy to see that L‚Üídùí©(0,1)L \overset{d}{\to} \mathcal{N}(0,1). Under the alternative, it can be shown that, approximately, L‚àºùí©(log(Œ∏)12J,1)L \sim \mathcal{N}(\text{log}(\theta)\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{J},1). If œà\psi is the average probability of an event per recruit in both arms (also known as the event rate), JJ can be replaced by 2‚ãÖn‚ãÖœà2 \cdot n \cdot \psi (where nn denotes, like in the previous sections, the number of recruits per group). Thus, by by postulating an event probability, we can calculate the number of recruits per groups that would be required to achieve a specific number of events, and by extensions, a specific power. In adoptr, the parameter œà\psi needs to be pre-specified in order to obtain a one-parametric distribution (the other parameter being Œ∏\theta), and œà\psi is assumed to be fixed over time. This is similar to the case of binary endpoints, where the response rate in the control group pCp_C had to be a constant value.

Survival analysis and adaptive designs

Notation

We expand the previous notation by an index k‚àà{1,2}k\in \{1,2\} denoting the current stage. We observe d1d_1 events until the interim analysis at times {1,‚Ä¶,J1}\{1,\dots,J_1\}, and we observe d2d_2 events in total until the final analysis at times {1,‚Ä¶,J2}\{1,\dots,J_2\}. We stress that, in this notation, d2d_2 denotes the cumulative number of events in both stages. Furthermore, let Oi,j,kO_{i,j,k} be the number of observed events in arm i‚àà{T,C}i\in \{T,C\} at time j‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,Jk}j \in \{1,\dots,J_k\} in stage k‚àà{1,2}k \in \{1,2\}. Like in the previous section, let Ei,j,k=ùîº[Oi,j,k]=ni,j,kOj,knj,kE_{i,j,k}= \mathbb{E}[O_{i,j,k}]=n_{i,j,k}\frac{O_{j,k}}{n_{j,k}}, where ni,j,kn_{i,j,k} is the number of patients that have not had an event until the end of stage kk, and let Oj,k=OT,j,k+OC,j,kO_{j,k}=O_{T,j,k}+O_{C,j,k} and nj,k=nT,j,k+nC,j,kn_{j,k}=n_{T,j,k}+n_{C,j,k}. Likewise, we can define Vi,j,kV_{i,j,k} analogously to the previous section. The cumulative log-rank test statistic up to stage k‚àà{1,2}k \in \{1, 2\} can then be defined as Lk=‚àëj=1JkOT,j,k‚àíET,j,k‚àëj=1JkVT,j,k. L_k=\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{J_k} O_{T,j,k}-E_{T,j,k}}{\sqrt{\sum_{j=1}^{J_k} V_{T,j,k}}}.

Dependency issues and solutions

For normal distributed endpoints, the stage-wise test statistics come from independent cohorts, which makes the calculation of their joint distributions straightforward.

In survival analysis, it is possible to have patients that have been recruited during the first stage, but have not had an event at the point of the interim analysis. Those provide information for both stages: in the first stage, we know that they survived, and in the second stage, they might die or even survive until the end of the trial. This makes the construction of a pair of suitable test statistics more challenging.

In the following, we will present two methods to avoid these issues.

Solution 1: Independent increments

It can be shown that the statistic Z2:=d2L2‚àíd1L1d2‚àíd1 Z_2:= \frac{\sqrt{d_2}L_2-\sqrt{d_1}L_1}{\sqrt{d_2-d_1}} is approximately distributed according to ùí©(log(Œ∏)12d2‚àíd1,1)\mathcal{N}(\text{log}(\theta)\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{d_2-d_1},1), and that L1L_1 and Z2Z_2 are approximately independent.

The recruitment and testing procedure is now as follows: During the accrual time, recruit approximately d12œà\frac{d_1}{2\psi} patients per group and conduct the interim analysis after having observed d1d_1 events overall.

Assume, qq patients have not had an event until the interim analysis. These patients are censored for the computation of L1L_1. L1L_1 is then compared to the futility and efficacy boundaries cfc_f and cec_e, and recruitment is stopped if L1<cfL_1 < c_f or L1>ceL_1 > c_e. If cf‚â§L1‚â§cec_f \leq L_1 \leq c_e, recruitment of patients for the second stage will continue.

The number of patients to be recruited in the second stage is calculated so that d2(L1)d_2(L_1) events are expected to be observed in the second stage. Similarly to the normal case, the required number of events is a function of the first-stage test statistic. The observation of these d2(L1)d_2(L_1) events will trigger the conduct of the final analysis, where Z2Z_2 is compared to c2(L1)c_2(L_1).

Solution 2: Left truncation at the second stage

Another approach uses left truncation and right censoring. In the following, RiR_i stands for the calendar time of entry for individual ii. Furthermore, let TiT_i be their time from entry to the event and CiC_i their time from entry to censoring. Assume that these values are independent and let ri,ti,cir_i,t_i,c_i be realizations of Ri,TiR_i,T_i and CiC_i. Additionally, we denote the calendar time of the interim analysis by tIntt_{Int} and the calender time of the final analysis by tFint_{Fin}.

Let individual ii be recruited before the interim analysis. Define yi,1:=min{ti,ci,tInt}y_{i,1}:=\min \{t_i,c_i,t_{Int}\}, i.e.¬†yi,1y_{i,1} can be interpreted as the minimum time until ‚Äúsomething‚Äù happens to individual ii in the first stage (either the interim analysis is conducted, ii had an event or they were censored). The risk interval for the first-stage test statistic is now defined to be (0,yi,1)(0,y_{i,1}), which means that individual ii belongs to the risk set at the event time tjt_j if min{ci,tInt‚àíri}‚â•xj\min \{c_i,t_{Int}-r_i\}\geq x_j.

If ii has not had an event yet in the first stage, was not lost to follow-up yet in the first stage, or if they were recruited in the second stage, we define yi,2:=min{ti,ci,tFin}y_{i,2}:=\min\{t_i,c_i,t_{Fin}\}. As before, yi,2y_{i,2} can be interpreted as the minimum time until something happens to individual ii in the second stage: Either the final analysis is conducted, ii had an event or was censored. The risk interval for an individual ii for the second stage test-statistic is then defined as (max(tInt‚àíri,0),yi,2)(\max(t_{Int}-r_i, 0),y_{i,2}). This definition takes into account that that a patient jj who was recruited in the first stage, but had no event until the interim analysis, has already provided the information of ‚Äúno event‚Äù in the time span (0,tInt‚àíri)(0, t_{Int}-r_i) for the interim analysis. To avoid double-counting in the second analysis, we say that this patient is not in the risk set until this time span is over.

Using this idea, one can conduct the analyses of the trial according to the following instructions: For the interim analysis, the procedure is the same as for the independent increment solution, i.e.¬†L1L_1 is computed in the usual way and compared to the futility and efficacy boundaries cfc_f and cec_e. If L1‚àà[ce,cf]L_1 \in [c_e,c_f] (i.e.¬†the trial is not stopped for early efficacy or futility), we continue the observation and recruit new patients, such that d2(L1)d_2(L_1) events are expected to be observed in the second stage.

The second-stage test statistic is where the two methods differ. Here, the idea is to construct a log-rank test statistic LTruncL_{Trunc} comprised of the data of the patients who were recruited after the interim analysis, who contribute to the test statistic in the usual way, and the patients recruited before the interim analysis who have not had an event yet, who contribute as left (and possibly right) truncated datapoints. In theory, this is can be achieved by appropriately adjusting njn_j for the respective event timings jj in the definition of the log-rank statistic, and in practice, the survival::coxph method can handle datasets of the aforementioned structure.

Example

In adoptr, trial designs to investigate time-to-event endpoints can be represented in objects of the class TwoStageDesignSurvival. These designs consist of slots for the first stage efficacy and futility boundaries cf and ce, a slot for the required number of events in the first stage n1, slots for the spline interpolation points for the n2 and c2 functions, and a postulated event rate œà\psi.

Two things are important to note here: First, the functions n1 and n2 will return the number of required events, not the number of recruits that would be required to achieve this number of events in expectation. Information on the latter is instead provided in the summary output of a design. Second, for one-armed trials, n1 and n2 are the overall number of required events, while for two-armed trials, n1 and n2 return half of the overall number of required events. This is analogous to the case with normally distributed outcomes, where n1 and n2 return the group-wise sample sizes. However, calling n1 and n2 the group-wise number of events would be a misnomer, as the timings of the interim analyses are based on the overall number of events, and the number of events are unlikely to be exactly equal across the two groups.

Let us say we want to plan a two-armed trial trial, where we assume an average rate of events of œà=0.7\psi=0.7.

datadist <- Survival(0.7, two_armed = TRUE)

The postulated rate of events œà\psi is saved in the DataDistribution object and will be handed down to any design optimized with respect to this distribution. It will be used to convert the required number of events dd to the estimated number of required recruits via dœà\frac{d}{\psi}, but it has no other uses. All other design parameters are invariant with respect to the choice of œà\psi.

Effect sizes for time-to-event trials are formulated with respect to a hazard ratio. For our example, we assume Œ∏=1\theta=1 for the null hypothesis, and a point alternative hypothesis of Œ∏=1.7\theta=1.7.

H_0 <- PointMassPrior(1, 1)
H_1 <- PointMassPrior(1.7, 1)

Our desired design should have a maximal type I error Œ±‚â§0.025\alpha\leq 0.025 and a minimum power of (1‚àíŒ≤)‚â•0.8(1-\beta)\geq 0.8.

alpha <- 0.025
min_power <- 0.8
toer_con <- Power(datadist,H_0) <= alpha
pow_con <- Power(datadist,H_1) >= min_power
exp_no_events <- ExpectedNumberOfEvents(datadist, H_1)
init <- get_initial_design(1.7, 0.025, 0.2, dist=datadist)
opt_survival <- minimize(exp_no_events, subject_to(toer_con,pow_con),
                         initial_design = init, check_constraints=TRUE)

summary(opt_survival$design)
#> For two-armed trials: nevs denotes half of the overall number of required events. nrec denotes the resulting group-wise sample size.
#> 
#> TwoStageDesignSurvival: nevs1= 32 --> nrec1= 46
#>           futility |                  continue                 | efficacy
#>       x1:     0.79 |  0.83  0.98  1.24  1.54  1.85  2.10  2.25 |  2.29
#>   c2(x1):     +Inf | +2.17 +2.02 +1.77 +1.43 +1.00 +0.52 +0.07 |  -Inf
#>   nevs2(x1):     0 |    45    42    38    32    24    17    12 |     0
#>   nrec2(x1):     0 |    64    60    54    45    35    25    17 |     0
#>

It should be noted that the number of required events 2‚ãÖ2\cdotnevs1 and 2‚ãÖ2\cdotnevs2(x1) are the important information thresholds to be adhered to for testing purposes. nrec1 and and nrec2(x1) only serve as rough estimates for the required number of recruits to achieve the target number of events. If additional information about e.g.¬†time-dependence of baseline hazards is available, it may be worthwhile to use a more sophisticated approach than the dœà\frac{d}{\psi} formula to estimate the number of required subjects.
